articles.description:
PARO, Bhutan, Oct 14 (IPS) - Zam, 57, sits at her kitchen table looking out the window at her orchard of four dozen apple trees. In the past eight years she has sold only two crates (100 kilogrammes) of the fruit because of poor harvests. She turned her attention to vegetables instead but the production was low because of a water shortage.

Read the full story, “Farmers in Bhutan Turn To Asparagus and Strawberries To Boost Incomes”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Farmers in Bhutan Turn To Asparagus and Strawberries To Boost Incomes

articles.description:
New York, Oct 14 (IPS) - In this year alone, the global impact of compounding crises demonstrates, more than ever, why food scarcity must be addressed internationally and how there must be a shift in the food and agricultural systems.

Read the full story, “World Food Day 2022 Call to Action as 828M People Go Hungry”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World Food Day 2022 Call to Action as 828M People Go Hungry

articles.description:
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct 14 (IPS) - Ten years ago, the Asia-Pacific region came together and designed the world’s first set of disability-specific development goals: the Incheon Strategy to “Make the Right Real” for Persons with Disabilities. This week, we meet again to assess how the governments have delivered on their commitments, to secure those gains and develop the innovative solutions needed to achieve fully inclusive societies.

Read the full story, “Persons with Disabilities Integral Players in Determining Innovative Solutions to Fully Inclusive Societies”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Persons with Disabilities Integral Players in Determining Innovative Solutions to Fully Inclusive Societies

articles.description:
BRUSSELS, Oct 14 (IPS) - The update on September 26, 2022, of the human rights situation in Myanmar to the UN Human Rights Council says it all: “The people of Myanmar have been caught in a rapid downward spiral, with growing suffering, fear, and insecurity. Urgent action is needed to reverse this catastrophic situation and to restore peace, democracy, and sustainable development”.

Read the full story, “Myanmar's Crisis Since the Coup-- in a Nutshell”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Myanmar's Crisis Since the Coup-- in a Nutshell

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Oct 14 (IPS) - The Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 has resulted in a never-ending flow of arms to the battle-scarred country— elevating the besieged nation to the ranks of one of the major recipients of US weapons and American security assistance.

Read the full story, “Ukraine Rises from Near Zero to Major Recipient of US Arms”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Ukraine Rises from Near Zero to Major Recipient of US Arms

articles.description:
The UN human rights office (OHCHR) expressed growing concern on Friday over the adoption by Turkiye’s Parliament of a package of amendments to various laws “that risk curtailing freedom of expression” in the country.

Read the full story, “Türkiye: Concern mounts over human rights implications of ‘disinformation bill’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Türkiye: Concern mounts over human rights implications of ‘disinformation bill’

articles.description:
In the face of the growing hunger crisis, the head of the UN Food and Agriculture Organization stressed on Friday, ahead of World Food Day, the need to “harness the power of solidarity and collective action” to build a sustainable world with enough to eat for everyone.

Read the full story, “Global food crisis: Let’s move from ‘despair to hope and action’, urges Guterres”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Global food crisis: Let’s move from ‘despair to hope and action’, urges Guterres

articles.description:
An unrelenting series of crises has trapped vulnerable Haitians in a cycle of growing desperation, without access to food, fuel, markets, jobs and public services, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Friday.

Read the full story, “‘Catastrophic’ hunger recorded in Haiti recorded for first time, UN warns”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ‘Catastrophic’ hunger recorded in Haiti recorded for first time, UN warns

articles.description:
CUZCO, Peru, Oct 13 (IPS) - This article forms part of IPS coverage of International Day of Rural Women, Oct. 15.Lourdes Barreto, 47, says that as an agroecological small farmer she has improved her life and that of Mother Earth. "I love myself as I love Mother Earth and I have learned to value both of us," she says in her field outside the village of Huasao, in the highlands of the southern Peruvian department of Cuzco.

Read the full story, “Agroecological Women Farmers Boost Food Security in Perus Highlands”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Agroecological Women Farmers Boost Food Security in Perus Highlands

articles.description:
Nairobi, Oct 13 (IPS) - IPBES’ assessment report on the Sustainable Use of Wild Species, released in July 2022, painted a troubling picture of the ongoing global biodiversity crisis that could paralyse economies and endanger food security and livelihoods.

Read the full story, “IPBES, IPCC Joint Winners of the Gulbenkian Prize for Humanity 2022 Dedicated to Climate Change”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: IPBES, IPCC Joint Winners of the Gulbenkian Prize for Humanity 2022 Dedicated to Climate Change

articles.description:
MADRID, Oct 13 (IPS) - A common feature to religions – including the monotheistic ones – is that groups of males have self-proclaimed themselves as the source for interpreting the “Word of God,” shaping them, and spreading them among the peoples of good faith.

Read the full story, “Millions of Girls Abused in the Name of Toxic Masculinity”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Millions of Girls Abused in the Name of Toxic Masculinity

articles.description:
PORTLAND, USA, Oct 13 (IPS) - Demography is at the heart of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as well as the fundamental obstacle to achieving to what each side has long desired: “שָׁלוֹם“ ,“سلام”, or “peace”

Read the full story, “Demography of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Demography of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Oct 13 (IPS) - As much of the world was starting to glimpse recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, it now finds itself amid a cost-of-living crisis brought on by disruptions in global energy and food markets that are the result of conflict and climate change.

Read the full story, “How Digital Can Drive a Green Recovery”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: How Digital Can Drive a Green Recovery

articles.description:
As protection, healthcare and essential services break down, the violence and volatile political and economic crisis engulfing Haiti has rapidly deteriorated into what the UN has described overall as a humanitarian catastrophe.

Read the full story, “Haiti: ‘Bearers of hope’, saving newborn lives, amid growing turmoil”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Haiti: ‘Bearers of hope’, saving newborn lives, amid growing turmoil

articles.description:
The world is at risk of yet another year of record hunger as the global food crisis continues to drive more people into worsening levels of acute food insecurity, The World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Thursday.

Read the full story, “World Food Day: Another year of global record hunger looms amid food and climate crisis”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World Food Day: Another year of global record hunger looms amid food and climate crisis

articles.description:
New uncertainty and “a heightened risk of war” now prevails across Yemen, following the end of a long truce which brought significant dividends, the UN Special Envoy Hans Grundberg told the Security Council on Thursday.

Read the full story, “Yemen: End of nationwide truce heralds ‘heightened risk of war’, Security Council hears”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Yemen: End of nationwide truce heralds ‘heightened risk of war’, Security Council hears

articles.description:
A new report from the UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction (UNDRR) and the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) published on Thursday, warns that half of the world’s countries are not protected by multi-hazard early warning systems.

Read the full story, “Disaster risk reduction: Only half the world equipped with adequate early warning systems”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Disaster risk reduction: Only half the world equipped with adequate early warning systems

articles.description:
SANTIAGO, Oct 12 (IPS) - In Magallanes, Chile's southernmost region, doubts and questions are being raised about the environmental impact of turning this area into the world's leading producer of green hydrogen.

Read the full story, “Doubts about Chiles Green Hydrogen Boom”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Doubts about Chiles Green Hydrogen Boom

articles.description: A fact-finding team tasked with investigating a deadly soccer stampede in Indonesia has concluded that tear gas was the main cause of death in one of the world's worst stadium disasters, the country's security minister said on Friday.

articles.description: Some 28.5% -- nearly one third -- of gas stations in mainland France are out of stock of at least one fuel, French Energy Transition Minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher told journalists Friday.

articles.description: New testing on a variety of popular branded sports bras and athletic wear has revealed high levels of BPA, a chemical compound that's used to make certain types of plastic and can lead to harmful health effects such as asthma, cardiovascular disease and obesity.

articles.description: Qatar's Emir Tamim al-Thani met with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the sidelines of a conference in Astana, Kazakhstan, on Thursday to "defuse tensions" between Moscow and Doha, a source familiar with the talks, but authorized to speak about them publicly, told CNN.

articles.description: A key inflation report showed consumer prices came in hotter than expected in September, punishing Americans and giving license to the Federal Reserve to maintain its pace of historic rate hikes.

articles.description: A court in military-run Myanmar has sentenced Aung San Suu Kyi, the country's deposed former leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner, to three additional years in jail for corruption, a source familiar with the case told CNN, extending her total prison term to 26 years.

articles.description: Four astronauts returned to Earth in a SpaceX capsule, ending their nearly six-month space station mission with a splashdown in the Atlantic off Florida. The capsule parachuted into the ocean, just off Jacksonville, Florida, about five hours after it left the space station. Wet and windy weather across Florida delayed their homecoming.

articles.description: A former chief justice of the Balochistan high court was gunned down as he came out of a mosque after offering prayers on Friday evening in Kharan area of Pakistan's restive Balochistan province. Muhammad Noor Maskanzai, who received multiple gun shot wounds, died while he was being taken to a hospital in Quetta, around 280 kilometres from the town of Kharan.

articles.description: A woman is raped in Pakistan every two hours, according to a recent survey, highlighting the unsafe conditions for women in the country where cases of honour killing is also rampant. The survey, which was conducted by a Pakistani channel's investigation unit, based on the data collected from the Punjab province's home department and ministry of human rights, also found that while the rape cases of women spiked, the conviction rate remained an abysmal 0.2 per cent.

A Q&A with Samantha Gross of the Brookings Institution on what OPEC’s cuts mean and where things might go from here.
 Ignoring months of lobbying by the White House, Saudi Arabia and other US allies in OPEC+ moved last week to slash the amount of oil on global markets. The countries of OPEC+ — a cartel of oil-producing nations — announced on October 5 that they would be decreasing the cartel’s production quota by 2 million barrels per day. A pedestrian walks along a bridge over the Moskva River in front of the Vodovzvodnaya tower of the Kremlin and the Russian Foreign Ministry headquarters in central Moscow on October 4, 2022. | Yuri Kadobnov/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
Three theories for a mysterious string of deaths in Putin’s Russia.
 It’s a rough year to be a high-profile Russian: After nearly eight months of war in Ukraine, the Russian military is reeling and on its back foot; sanctions continue to squeeze the country’s economy and elite — and at least 15 Russian businessmen and executives have died in apparent accidents or by suicide, including a number of Putin allies.
The victims range from an executive with Gazprom, a major state-owned oil company, to the managing director of a state-run development corporation. T…
articles.title: Russian businessmen keep dying. No one knows why.

articles.description: Former President Donald Trump is reportedly considering testifying in front of the committee investigating last year's Capitol riot.
articles.title: 'Answer for his actions' Ex-POTUS Donald Trump may appear before January 6 committee

articles.description: On September 21, the Russian President announced that 300,000 reservists with military experience or education would be called up, a move that followed significant counter-attacks by Kyiv's forces in eastern and southern Ukraine.
articles.title: Ukraine war: Vladimir Putin claims reservist mobilisation will be completed in two weeks

articles.description: Vladimir Putin is giving a press conference in which he said he has 'no regrets' over the war in Ukraine.
articles.title: Ukraine LIVE: 'We'll see!' Putin leaves door open for 'massive strike' in chilling address

articles.description: KAMALA HARRIS has been accused of having "lived under a rock" after the Vice President delivered a speech attacking United States's treatment of Native Americans.
articles.title: Kamala Harris slammed after attack on America's 'shameful' history 'Living under a rock!'

articles.description: Officials said Western governments are preparing to prevent people from panicking in the event of a nuclear attack in Ukraine.
articles.title: Western nations plan to calm people if Kremlin launches Ukraine nuke attack

articles.description: Sixty years ago today, pictures taken by a US spy plane over Cuba triggered arguably the biggest international crisis in history - until now.
articles.title: Nuclear war threat worse than at height of Cuban Missile Crisis, warns ex-defence minister

articles.description: Video footage from within Ukraine has captured Moscow's armed forces surrendering to Ukrainian troops as Kyiv's counter-offensive advances into occupied regions
articles.title: Mobilised Russian soldiers surrender to Ukrainian forces as troops turn against Kremlin

articles.description: Police are following a lead which may link the Stockton, California serial killer to two people killed in Chicago in 2018.
articles.title: Police eye breakthrough in Stockton serial killer case with 'duck walk' murderer probe

articles.description: Furious protests have been widespread throughout the country following the death in custody of Mahsa Amini exactly a month ago.
articles.title: Iranian regime 'kills 23 children' as Islamic Republic tries to crush demonstrations

articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin ended his visit to Kazakhstan on Friday for the summit of the post-Soviet organisation Commonwealth of Independent States .
articles.title: Putin meets with old Soviet Union alliance as he plots breakaway from West over Ukraine

articles.description: Ukrainian trainees with little or no military experience are being versed in how to use advanced anti-tank weaponry in Britain before returning home to take on Vladimir Putin's men.
articles.title: Ukrainian recruits learn to use powerful Javelin missiles in UK training programme

articles.description: Russia's President has ramped up his threats of using nuclear weapons over recent weeks as the EU and NATO promise fierce retaliation.
articles.title: 'Not bluffing either': EU chief warns Putin army would be 'annihilated' after nuclear hit

articles.description: A significant majority of 143 United Nations members voted to condemn Russia's attempted annexations of Ukraine in a vote on Wednesday, but others abstained or voted against the motion.
articles.title: Russia UN vote: Every country that abstained in key vote on Russian annexation

articles.description: The video of a screaming baby has been viewed more than 10.4million times on TikTok, since yesterday.
articles.title: Crying baby on 29-hour flight sparks debate as travellers demand child-free flights

articles.description: Great Britain has already given Ukraine thousands of anti-tank, anti-ship and anti-aircraft missiles, including Starstreak, NLAW and Brimstone missiles.
articles.title: Ukraine LIVE: Putin faced with mass desertion after 150 troops killed in precision strike

articles.description: Germany has been desperately trying to cut a heavy reliance on Russian oil and gas since the start of the Ukraine war.
articles.title: 'No regrets' for Angela Merkel as she hits back at critics over Russian gas reliance

articles.description: President Lukashenko has ordered troops to deploy with Russian forces near the Ukraine border, and his defence ministry says "combat readiness" drills are underway. On Tuesday, the interior ministry held exercises to eliminate "sabotage groups" near Yelsk, only 20km from the border with Ukraine.
articles.title: Lukashenko's border war bluff unmasked as false flag operation: 'No sign of invasion'

articles.description: The massive relic of the Soviet era will now be converted into a museum.
articles.title: Putin parades 3,000 tonne Soviet nuclear submarine through streets of Russia

articles.description: The Iranian government has perpetrated brutal crackdowns against protesters, with over 100 feared dead.
articles.title: Iranian actress strips niqab and goes topless in powerful protest against Islamic Republic

articles.description: Russia has recently threatened to use nuclear weapons as it continues to lose its war in Ukraine.
articles.title: Ukraine LIVE: NATO ready for 'physical response' if Putin keeps to nuclear threats

articles.description: Ukrainian troops have continued to regain more territory from Russia and welcomed fresh Western air defences being delivered.
articles.title: Triumph for Zelensky's forces as four Russian helicopters shot down in just '18 minutes'

articles.description: The self-governed island has been stockpiling "critical supplies" for years in an attempt to prepare for a potential blockade or attack from China as it fears "intimidation or coercion" from Beijing.
articles.title: Taiwan demands China to halt drones in fresh threat - ‘War will be declared!’

articles.description: Vladimir Putin has sent a thinly disguised threat to Ukraine allies of a danger to global infrastructure as the Kremlin accuses Ukraine of sabotaging its Nord Stream pipeline.
articles.title: Putin warns of ‘terror’ risk to global infrastructure after ‘dangerous precedent’ was set

articles.description: Tens of thousands of Russian troops are thought to have been killed during the conflict as troops struggle with advances into key Ukrainian regions.
articles.title: Russia's 'irrecoverable losses' hit '90,000' in Ukraine war as Putin's plan crumbles

articles.description: The North-Korean leader has recently ramped up missile launches as a result of the recent drills performed by South Korea and the United States.
articles.title: Kim Jong-Un personally takes over guidance of cruise missile in latest North Korean test

articles.description: Alistair Blake, 61, went to the "other side" and back as paramedics found a pulse after trying for 90 minutes to save him from a cardiac arrest.
articles.title: ‘I was gone for 90 minutes': Man who 'returned from the dead' reveals his experience

articles.description: Ex-Prime Minister Boris Johnson has embarked on a new career after leaving Downing Street last month.
articles.title: Boris pockets £130k for speech in US – and receives a standing ovation afterwards

sources.title: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: An explosion inside a coal mine in northern Turkey on Friday left 14 people dead, at least 28 injured and nearly 50 trapped underground, Interior Minister Suleyman Soylu said.
articles.title: Rescuers in Turkey race to reach trapped coal miners after deadly blast

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Two brothers were on Friday jailed for 40 years each for the car bomb murder of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia who uncovered corruption in high places and whose killing sparked an international furore and forced the resignation of the prime minister.
articles.title: Brothers sentenced to 40 years in prison for murdering Maltese journalist Caruana Galizia

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Environmental protesters threw tomato soup over one of Vincent van Gogh's "Sunflowers" paintings at London's National Gallery on Friday, in the latest "direct-action" stunt targeting works of art.
articles.title: Climate activists target art: Van Gogh’s masterpiece 'Sunflowers' defaced

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Robbie Coltrane, the baby-faced comedian and character actor whose hundreds of roles included a crime-solving psychologist on the TV series “Cracker” and the gentle half-giant Hagrid in the “Harry Potter” movies, has died. He was 72.
articles.title: Scottish actor Robbie Coltrane, who played Hagrid in Harry Potter films, dies at 72

articles.author: Joanna YORK
articles.description: As missile strikes in Ukraine this week damaged libraries, museums and universities, Ukraine says repeated Russian attacks on cultural heritage amount to a “war crime” that have caused losses of hundreds of millions of euros. Among Ukrainians, the fight to preserve cultural heritage continues.
articles.title: “Cultural cleansing”: New Russian attacks on Ukraine spur cultural preservation efforts

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Embattled UK Prime Minister Liz Truss has appointed Jeremy Hunt to replace Kwasi Kwarteng as Finance Minister on Friday, while also ditching the cut in corporation tax in a major U-turn to her mini-budget announced just last month triggering major market turmoil.
articles.title: UK PM Truss U-turn on mini budget, raises corporation tax and names Hunt finance minister

articles.description: Despite online censorship, photos and videos shared online show a rare protest against the Chinese government in Beijing. The dramatic demonstration took place on a highway bridge on October 13, just days before the 20th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party convenes. The protest seems to have been initiated by just one person, who has been widely praised online.
articles.title: 'Remove the dictator Xi Jinping': Images show rare protest in Beijing

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Political parties, social and religious groups and representatives of the security forces were gathering Friday to chart the next phase in Burkina Faso's future after the country's latest coup.
articles.title: Burkina Faso holds transition talks after latest coup

articles.author: Nicolas SPICER
articles.description: In the past few decades, Somalia’s droughts have increased both in intensity and in number due to climate change. It is now facing a famine that threatens the lives of millions of people, especially children. The United Nations says there are staggering levels of malnutrition among children under the age of five. The last major famine in Somalia, which dates to 2011, claimed 260,000 lives and remains vivid in locals' minds.
articles.title: Somalia: The curse of famine

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The leader of Sweden's Moderates party, Ulf Kristersson, said on Friday he had agreed a deal with the Christian Democrats and the Liberals to form a minority coalition government after the right-wing bloc won a majority in last month's election.
articles.title: Sweden’s Moderates party strikes minority govt deal with far-right backing

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Two NGOs have filed a complaint against French energy giant TotalEnergies for "complicity in war crimes" for allegedly helping fuel Russian planes that have bombed Ukraine, according to French media reports.
articles.title: France’s TotalEnergies faces legal case for allegedly fuelling Russian bombers

articles.author: Rawad TAHA
articles.description: Almost three years into Lebanon’s trifecta of economic, social and political crises, many Lebanese are desperate to find solutions. With no reliable source of electricity, those who can afford it are leading a shift towards green energy, predominantly solar.
articles.title: Lebanese turn to solar energy amid collapse of national power grid

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: TotalEnergies on Friday said the company had signed a salary agreement with two French unions. With the hardline CGT union walking out of negotiations, however, France continued to face fuel shortages ahead of a general public sector strike next week.
articles.title: Two French unions sign agreement with TotalEnergies, but CGT continues strike

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin said Friday he sees “no need” to hold talks with US President Joe Biden, who said earlier this week that the possibility of meeting with the Russian leader on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Bali in November “would depend” on what Putin wanted to discuss. Putin, speaking in the Kazakh capital, also said that his attendance at the summit was “not finalised”. Read FRANCE 24’s liveblog to catch up on the day's events as they unfolded. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: Putin sees ‘no need’ for Biden talks, undecided on whether he will attend G20

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: A shooting Thursday in North Carolina's capital Raleigh left at least five people dead, including an off-duty police officer, officials in the southeast US city said, adding that a suspect had been captured.
articles.title: At least five killed in North Carolina shooting, suspect arrested

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Elon Musk is under a federal investigation related to his $44 billion takeover deal for Twitter Inc TWTR.N, the social media company said in a court filing made public on Thursday.
articles.title: Elon Musk under federal investigation over $44bn Twitter deal

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Turkey's parliament on Thursday adopted a law proposed by President Tayyip Erdogan that would jail journalists and social media users for up to three years for spreading "disinformation", despite deep concerns over free speech.
articles.title: Turkey adopts new 'disinformation' law that could jail journalists

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: North Korea on Friday test fired a short-range ballistic missile and flew nearly a dozen fighter jets close to the border with the South, Yonhap news agency reported – the latest in a series of military provocations that have sent tensions soaring on the Korean peninsula.
articles.title: North Korea launches ballistic missile into sea after flying warplanes near border

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The US House of Representatives committee investigating the January 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol voted on Thursday to subpoena Donald Trump, an action that could eventually result in the former president's imprisonment if he does not comply.
articles.title: US January 6 panel votes to compel Trump to testify over Capitol assault

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Palestinian factions signed a reconciliation deal in Algiers on Thursday, vowing to hold elections by next October in their latest attempt to end a rift that has now lasted more than 15 years.
articles.title: Palestinian rivals Hamas and Fatah sign reconciliation deal in Algiers

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Did the West misread China the way it misread Russia? Former Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd compares the ‘business first’ era of yesteryear with the nationalist bend as Xi Jinping further consolidates his grip on power. The Chinese Communist Party’s lifting of term limits for its president signals a possible return to the sort of one-man rule seen under Mao, the now-president of the Asia Society think tank tells François Picard. Rudd also asserts why the war in Ukraine is the whole world’s business and why he feels that Vladimir Putin’s threats have backfired badly.
articles.title: China now under one-man rule? Former Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd weighs in on Xi Jinping

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: A US jury on Thursday rejected the death penalty for Nikolas Cruz, who shot and killed 17 people at his former Florida high school, opting instead for life imprisonment without the chance of parole.
articles.title: Florida jury recommends Parkland shooter get life in jail for US school massacre

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Despite a rocket attack on Baghdad's Green Zone, Iraqi lawmakers Thursday elected a new president who swiftly named a prime minister in hopes of ending a year of political gridlock and violence in the war-scarred nation.
articles.title: Iraq gets new president and prime minister after year of deadlock

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: With climate change bringing higher temperatures, UK winemakers are increasingly able to grow grape varieties traditionally associated with warmer climes, such as pinot noir and chardonnay, and may soon be able to work with grapes normally grown even further south if global warming trends continue, experts say.
articles.title: 'Perfect climate': Global warming heats up UK winemaking

articles.author: David RICH
articles.description: Russia has unleashed a deluge of missile strikes on Ukraine in retaliation for the blast on Saturday that damaged the bridge to Crimea. Several military experts feel this operation is counterproductive as Moscow is struggling to replenish its weapons stocks.
articles.title: Strikes in Ukraine shine a spotlight on dwindling Russian missile stocks

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: At least three rockets hit Baghdad’s Green Zone on Thursday as a parliamentary session was about to meet to elect a new president and break a political gridlock.
articles.title: Rockets hit Baghdad’s Green Zone as Iraqi MPs meet to elect president

articles.author: Dheepthika LAURENT
articles.description: IN THE PAPERS - Thursday, October 13: We look at this bombshell report from French investigate website Mediapart about Paris Saint Germain hiring a digital troll army to smear its critics and detractors, including its own star player Kylian Mbappé. The Washington Post looks at a marriage celebrant in Utah County who is marrying gay couples around the world over Zoom. Finally, a new docuseries on Barney the Dinosaur sheds light on why the children's icon, once so loved, became so hated.
articles.title: PSG hired army of digital trolls to smear critics, new French investigative report finds

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: French railway workers and civil servants voted on Thursday to join striking oil refinery staff with a walkout next week  after the French government resorted to emergency powers to compel some fuel depot workers to return to their jobs in a bid to ease petrol shortages.
articles.title: French strikes spread as government orders fuel depot staff back to work

articles.author: Tom WHEELDON
articles.description: The Chinese Communist Party Congress opens in Beijing on October 16, a week after Washington imposed tight restrictions on exports of invaluable semiconductor technology to China in a bid to stop it from surpassing the US economically and militarily. As semiconductors emerge as a key battleground, FRANCE 24 spoke to the author of a new bestseller on these all-important pieces of silicon.
articles.title: Why semiconductors are central to world economy, geopolitics

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: On September 13, Mahsa Amini was arrested by Iran’s morality police in Tehran for allegedly breaching the country’s severe dress code for women. Days later, the 22-year-old Iranian woman died in custody, triggering mass protests and crackdowns that have claimed more than 100 lives, according to a human rights group. The discontent has spread, posing a serious challenge to the Islamic republic.
articles.title: One month after Mahsa Amini’s arrest, Iran protest deaths top 100

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin would be crossing a “very important line” if he were to order the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg warned on Thursday, with Russia set to hold nuclear exercises in the coming days. Earlier, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan defended Ankara's booming trade ties with Moscow during a meeting with Putin in Kazakhstan, resisting Western pressure to comply with sanctions against Russia. Follow FRANCE 24’s live blog for all the latest developments. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: Live: NATO chief says Russia would cross ‘very important line’ with nuclear strike

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The world's wildlife populations have declined by more than two-thirds since 1970 as forests have been cleared and oceans polluted, according to an assessment released on Thursday.
articles.title: Global wildlife populations have plunged almost 70% since 1970, says WWF

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The United States on Wednesday said it will boost support for the Haitian police as they battle armed gangs and will speed up delivery of aid to a country suffering from crippling shortages of basic goods due to a gang blockade of a key fuel terminal.
articles.title: US promises to deliver aid to Haiti and help local police counter armed gangs

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Right-wing conspiracy theorist Alex Jones must pay at least $965 million in damages to numerous families of victims of the 2012 Sandy Hook mass shooting for falsely claiming they were actors who faked the tragedy, a Connecticut jury said on Wednesday.
articles.title: Alex Jones ordered to pay Sandy Hook families nearly $1 billion for false claims

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Alphabet Inc's GOOGL.O Google has approved former U.S. President Donald Trump's social media app Truth Social for distribution in the Google Play Store, a company spokesperson said on Wednesday.
articles.title: Google approves Trump's Truth Social for distribution in Play Store

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Mohamed Salah came off the bench to score the fastest hat-trick in Champions League history as Liverpool thrashed Rangers 7-1 on Wednesday to put one foot in the Champions League last 16.
articles.title: Salah hat-trick helps Liverpool beat Rangers in Champions League

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un oversaw the launch of two long-range strategic cruise missiles, state media reported on Thursday, calling it a test to confirm the reliability and operation of nuclear-capable weapons deployed to military units.
articles.title: North Korea says it test-fired cruise missiles able to carry nuclear weapons

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: France will deliver radar and air defence systems to Ukraine in the coming weeks to help the country protect itself from Russian drone and missile attacks, French President Emmanuel Macron said on Wednesday, adding that the war had entered "an unprecedented stage".
articles.title: France to supply air defence systems to Ukraine after wave of Russian strikes

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: About 500 people have died in Nigeria's worst floods in a decade and 1.4 million others have been displaced from their homes since the start of the rainy season, the government said.
articles.title: Nigeria's worst floods in a decade kill 500, displace 1.4 million

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Chadian ruler Mahamat Idriss Deby pushed ahead Wednesday with declared plans to steer the country back to civilian government, appointing a former opposition figure as prime minister to head an interim administration of "national union".
articles.title: Chad's Deby taps ex-opposition figure Saleh Kebzabo to head interim cabinet

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: The Kome Caves in Lesotho have been occupied since the 19th century, when tribes fleeing conflict and drought took refuge there. Two hundred years later, a handful of families, many the descendants of those original tribes, are still making a life in the simple mud dwellings despite daily hardships that include problems with their water supply and frequently finding themselves cut off from the outside world.
articles.title: Lesotho: Cave dwellers vow to stay despite hardships

articles.description: Did the commander-in-chief of Ukraine's armed forces publish a photo of himself wearing a bracelet with a swastika on it? That’s what some Russian media outlets and pro-Russian social media accounts have been reporting since October 9, 2022. While the photo is authentic, the compression of the image and the poor resolution quality make it possible to mistake the symbol on his bracelet for the Nazi cross. In reality, however, it is a Celtic knot.
articles.title: No, this Ukrainian general isn’t wearing a bracelet with a swastika on it

articles.author: Sébastian SEIBT
articles.description: President Alexander Lukashenko announced on Monday that Belarus will more actively support its Russian ally in the war against Ukraine. Analysts say Lukashenko is reluctant to send troops – especially since a wave of protests in 2020 exposed his immense unpopularity at home – but is likely caving to pressure from Russian President Vladimir Putin.
articles.title: ‘Russian pressure is too strong’: Is Putin pulling Belarus into the war in Ukraine?

sources.title: World News - Breaking international news and headlines | Sky News

articles.description: Global conservation experts have issued a code red alert for the state of nature as human exploitation pushes the planet's life support systems to the brink.
articles.title: Human exploitation 'pushing Earth's life support systems to the brink'

articles.description: Qatar's World Cup chief has told the English and Welsh FAs to focus on their teams rather than demanding compensation for migrant workers.
articles.title: Turning World Cup into 'platform of political statements' is  'not right for football', Qatar boss says

articles.description: North Korea says it has test-fired long range cruise missiles, hitting a target 1,240 miles (2,000km) away.
articles.title: North Korea test-fires cruise missiles which 'hit target 1,240 miles away'

articles.description: The French government has ordered some fuel depot strikers back to work, risking a bigger row with unions as it tries to secure petrol supplies.
articles.title: French government orders fuel depot strikers back to work amid union showdown

articles.description: The chancellor's mini-budget "complicated matters" for the Bank of England as it battled to bring down inflation, the International Monetary Fund's chief economist has told Sky News.
articles.title: Mini-budget 'complicated' Bank of England's battle to bring down inflation - IMF

articles.description: American Idol runner-up Willie Spence has died in a car crash in the US.
articles.title: American Idol runner-up Willie Spence dies in car crash at the age of 23

articles.description: Two fishermen fought off sharks after their boat sank off the Louisiana coast while a third swam to search for help.
articles.title: 'I punched him in the face and jabbed him in the eyes': Fisherman tells how he fought off sharks as boat sank

articles.description: Nagib's small feet poke out from a bundled blue shroud. His body is far too small for his three years of age.
articles.title: Drought, disease and conflict: Somalia is fighting a battle on all fronts

articles.description: Ireland's football association and the women's team manager have apologised after players sang a song referencing the IRA while celebrating their World Cup qualification.
articles.title: Ireland women players who sang song referencing IRA after qualifying win apologise

articles.description: A deliberate attack on NATO energy supplies will be met with a "united and determined response", the alliance's chief has vowed.
articles.title: Attack on NATO energy supplies would provoke 'determined response'

articles.description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant is strategically critical to both sides of the Ukraine-Russia conflict. But in terms of nuclear safety, the ongoing stalemate is perilous.
articles.title: Why Ukraine's disputed nuclear plant remains an accident waiting to happen

articles.description: The woman behind an image of a buzzing ball of cactus bees spinning over the hot sand on a Texas ranch has been named winner of this year's Wildlife Photographer Of The Year competition.
articles.title: Wildlife Photographer Of The Year: Best animal and nature images of 2022 revealed as winners announced

articles.description: The prime suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann in 2007 has been charged in Germany with several sexual offences allegedly committed in Portugal.
articles.title: Madeleine McCann suspect charged with several sexual offences by German prosecutors

articles.description: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has predicted a tough 2023 as it cut growth predictions and forecast economic contraction in a third of the world.
articles.title: 'The worst is yet to come': IMF says 2023 will 'feel like a recession'

articles.description: New Zealand farmers are resisting government plans to tax the greenhouse gases that farm animals make from burping and peeing in an attempt to curb climate breakdown.
articles.title: New Zealand plan to tax cow and sheep burps faces backlash

articles.description: A "historic deal" has been signed by Lebanon and Israel that has the potential to ease security and economic concerns in both countries.
articles.title: Lebanon and Israel sign 'historic' deal that could help avoid a 'sure-fire war in the region'

articles.description: The number killed by landslides in Venezuela has risen to at least 36 people after the country was hit by flooding and days of torrential rain.
articles.title: At least 36 killed by Venezuela landslides as number of dead rises

articles.description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy was defiant as he vowed to make the battlefield "more painful" for Russian troops after another deadly day of rockets raining down on Ukraine.
articles.title: Zelenskyy vows to make battlefield 'more painful' for Russians after another day of deadly rocket strikes

articles.description: A third of petrol stations were out of one or more types of fuel in France on Monday as fuel strikes continued for a 13th day, according to the country's energy ministry.
articles.title: Third of petrol stations out of fuel in France as strikes continue

articles.description: Russia is running out of weapons for its war in Ukraine and the costs to the Kremlin are "staggering" in terms of soldiers killed and equipment lost, a UK spy chief will say.
articles.title: Russia running out of weapons as it faces 'staggering' numbers of casualties, spy chief says

articles.description: As missiles rained down on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities, many people took refuge in underground metro stations.
articles.title: 'It united our spirit': Ukrainians sing while sheltering from missile attacks

articles.description: In the village by the deep lake - signified by its Irish name: An Craoslach (The Gorge Lake) - they're experiencing deep grief.
articles.title: Amid deep grief there is a strong sense of community in this village after Donegal explosion

articles.description: On Moscow's Ukrainsky or Ukrainian Boulevard, the statue of one of Ukraine's most famous 19th century poets, Lesya Ukrainka, looks down benevolently across the open space towards the towering Hotel Ukraine.
articles.title: Opinions divided in Moscow after Kremlin's escalation in Ukraine

articles.description: The airline Air France and plane maker Airbus have gone on trial on manslaughter charges over a passenger jet crash which killed all 228 people on board.
articles.title: 'Shame': Angry relatives of plane crash victims shout at Air France and Airbus bosses during manslaughter trial

articles.description: A former Liberian rebel is on trial accused of committing crimes against humanity, torture and acts of barbarism during the civil war in his country.
articles.title: Former Liberian rebel on trial for crimes against humanity, including pulling a man's heart out of his body

articles.description: Russian forces will soon be down to their last supplies of fuel and unable to transport their troops in Ukraine after the crippling attack on the Kerch Bridge between Crimea and Russia, say analysts.
articles.title: Russian forces 'will soon be down to their last supplies of fuel' after Kerch Bridge attack

articles.description: Two men have been charged over the alleged attack on Prince Andrew's heckler in Scotland
articles.title: Two men charged over alleged attack on Prince Andrew heckler

articles.author: A. D. Rothman
articles.description: 65 years ago, Russia’s launched the first man-made satellite, signalling the dawn of the Space Age. Sputnik’s launch wounded America’s “national ego” and was likened to a “bloodless Pearl Harbour”.
articles.title: From the Archives, 1957: Cold War intensifies as Russia launches Sputnik

articles.author: Sherryn Groch
articles.description: Ukraine’s army is winning back territory almost as fast as Russia claims to have taken it over. How are the latest twists in the Ukraine crisis unfolding? And why is everyone talking about nukes?
articles.title: Russia has annexed more of Ukraine. What does that mean and what happens now?

articles.description: A neighbour's doorbell security camera has captured the moment a helicopter crashed in a Californian yard, hurting a pilot and passenger.
articles.title: Moment helicopter crashes into California yard

articles.description: Watch the anger unfold after contestants in a fishing competition are found to have added weights to their fish ahead of judging.
articles.title: We've got weights in fish

articles.author: Latika Bourke
articles.description: The new prime minister distanced herself from her government’s controversial tax policy, describing it as a decision made by the chancellor.
articles.title: MPs warned against tax cut rebellion as Truss concedes ‘communication mistakes’

articles.description: A Sherpa has filmed an avalanche rolling across base camp on the world's eighth highest mountain.
articles.title: Avalanche strikes Manaslu base camp

articles.author: Vimal Patel
articles.description: Video captured the moment – “We got weights in fish!” – that scandalised the lucrative Cleveland fishing contest.
articles.title: Fishing contest rocked after weights found in winning catches

articles.author: Dera Menra Sijabat and Sui-Lee Wee
articles.description: Joshua and his friends were seated in the stands when fan frustration turned into violence and tragedy at a top-flight soccer match.
articles.title: ‘I can still hear voices screaming,’ says fan at Malang stadium disaster

articles.author: Jon Gambrell
articles.description: Russia’s loss of the eastern city of Lyman, which it had been using as a transport and logistics hub, is a new blow to the Kremlin.

articles.author: Sebastian Rotella and Kirsten Berg, ProPublica
articles.description:
ProPublica is a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative newsroom. Sign up for The Big Story newsletter to receive stories like this one in your inbox.

In 2017, Drug Enforcement Administration agents following the money from cocaine deals in Memphis, Tennessee, identified a mysterious figure in Mexico entrusted by drug lords with their millions: a Chinese American gangster named Xizhi Li.
As the agents tracked Li’s activity across the Americas and Asia, they realized he wasn’t just another money launderer. He was a pioneer. Operating with the acumen of a financier and the tradecraft of a spy, he had helped devise an innovative system that revolutionized the drug underworld and fortified the cartels.
Li hit on a better way to address a problem that has long bedeviled the world’s drug lords: ho…
articles.title: Here's how a mysterious Chinese American gangster transformed money laundering for drug cartels

articles.author: Sky Palma
articles.description:
In a move White House officials called a "hostile act," Saudi Arabia slashed oil production by 2 million barrels a day with around just a month to go before the U.S. midterms. Now, the Biden administration says it will be "re-evaluating" its relationship with the Saudis. 
According to The Intercept's Ken Klippenstein, the reaction was a public sign of disappointment from U.S. officials rarely directed towards the Saudi Kingdom. 
Experts speaking to The Intercept say the Saudis' move wasn't just geopolitical -- it was an effort to influence U.S. politics. 
“The Saudis are working to get Trump re-elected and for the MAGA Republicans to win the midterms,” Bruce Riedel, a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution, told The Intercept. “Higher oil prices will undermine the Democrats.”
IN OTHER …
articles.title: Saudi Arabia's oil price hike is 'election interference' designed to hurt Democrats: experts

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The coronation of King Charles III will take place on May 6 next year, Buckingham Palace announced on Tuesday, vowing to reflect the monarchy's historic traditions and its modern role.
Charles, 73, will be formally crowned at London's Westminster Abbey, following a long tradition dating back more than 900 years.
The monarch's wife, Queen Consort Camilla, 75, will also be crowned, the palace confirmed.
May 6 is the fourth birthday of Charles' grandson Archie, the son of Prince Harry and his wife Meghan.
"The coronation will reflect the monarch's role today and look towards the future, while being rooted in longstanding traditions and pageantry," royal officials said in a short statement.
The much-anticipated confirmation of the date comes just over a month after the death of Charles' mother…
articles.title: King Charles III to be crowned in May

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
The Justice Department announced that a British property manager with ties to Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska has been charged with violating sanctions. 
Graham Bonham Carter is being charged with "conspiring to violate United States sanctions imposed on Russian oligarch Oleg Vladimirovich Deripaska and wire fraud in connection with BONHAM-CARTER’s funding of U.S. properties purchased by Deripaska and efforts to expatriate Deripaska’s artwork in the U.S. through misrepresentations," wrote the Justice Department in an announcement. 
Deripaska, a Russian billionaire with close ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin, was able to wiggle his way into a lucrative deal with Donald Trump's government in 2019. 
Bonham Carter was arrested Tuesday in the UK and the United States is seeking his extr…
articles.title: A property manager with ties to oligarch Oleg Deripaska has been charged with violating sanctions on Russia

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky called on Tuesday for wealthy Western nations to help Kyiv create an "air shield" after a rash of deadly Russian aerial attacks.
Zelensky, who told the G7 club of rich nations "millions of people would be grateful" for help fending off attacks from the sky, warned Russia "still has room for further escalation" after Monday's bloody missile salvoes across
Following the attacks, Washington pledged to up shipments of air defenses to Ukraine, while Germany promised delivery "in the coming days" of the first Iris-T missile shield reportedly capable of protecting a city.
In a week of marked escalation in the war, G7 leaders said that Belarus's plan to deploy joint forces with Russia constituted a new instance of "complicity" with Moscow, warning Minsk to "stop…
articles.title: Zelensky pleads for Ukraine 'air shield' after Russian onslaught

articles.author: Brad Reed
articles.description:
An explosive new report claims that Tesla CEO Elon Musk spoke directly with Russian President Vladimir Putin before he floated a "peace plan" for Ukraine that was widely panned by critics as a gift to Russia.
Vice News reports that newsletter from Ian Bremmer, a foreign policy expert and the founder of the Eurasia Group global risk consultancy firm, is claiming that Musk said that Putin is now "prepared to negotiate" a peace settlement but only if Ukraine accepted Russia's annexations of its territories in the eastern part of the country.
Putin emphasized to Musk that Russia's annexation of this Ukrainian territory, as well as an agreement in which Ukraine would maintain neutrality and not join NATO, would be accomplished "no matter what," and he even emphasized that his nation was prepared to launch a nuclear strike should Ukrainian forces attempt to retake Crimea, which Russia annexed in 2014.
Bremmer also claims that Musk personally told him that "everything needed to be done to avoid that outcome," and that was why he publicly floated his plan.
IN OTHER NEWS: Now Trump is openly challenging the feds to indict him
But Musk's plan has not been well received in Kyiv, with many officials saying it would amount to capitulation to Russia.
"The only outcome is that now no Ukrainian will EVER buy your f...ing tesla crap. So good luck to you," Ukrainian Ambassador to Germany Andrij Melnyk wrote to Musk on Twitter. "F*ck off is my very diplomatic reply to you."
Musk has denied Bremmer's claims, however, and he wrote on Twitter that "I have spoken to Putin only once and that was about 18 months ago. The subject matter was space."
NOW WATCH: ‘Nobody should have to go to jail for smoking weed’: VP Kamala Harris urges state pardons


‘Nobody should have to go to jail for smoking weed’ VP Kamala Harris urges state pardons

www.youtube.com
articles.title: Elon Musk denies he spoke with Putin before floating widely panned Ukraine 'peace' plan: report

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
President Joe Biden is to "re-evaluate" the US relationship with Saudi Arabia in light of the OPEC+ decision to cut oil production, a White House spokesperson said Tuesday.
"I think the president's been very clear that this is a relationship that we need to continue to re-evaluate, that we need to be willing to revisit," National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby told CNN.
"Certainly in light of the OPEC decision, I think that's where he is."
The 13-nation, Saudi-led OPEC cartel and its 10 allies headed by Russia agreed last week to reduce output by two million barrels a day from November -- raising fears that oil prices could soar.
The decision was widely seen as a diplomatic slap in the face, since Biden traveled to Saudi Arabia in July and met with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salma…
articles.title: Biden to 're-evaluate' Saudi ties after OPEC snub: White House

articles.description: MIAMI — Minutes before taking the stage, Tina Karol, sparkling in a blue-and-yellow ombre dress, was presented with a gift from a young admirer: a matching homemade bracelet with beads that spell out her name. She smiled, and hastily wrapped the bracelet around her wrist. She then rushed into a curtain, the crowd roaring as smoke filled the stage. Some even wiped away their tears as Karol began the show. Karol, a well-known Ukrainian singer, is an artist, actress and show presenter. She’s also a philanthropist and the founder of a nonprofit called The Pole of Attraction. She rose to prominence...
